content.webTitle: NHS accused of racial discrimination on pay for senior doctors

fields.headline: NHS accused of racial discrimination on pay for senior doctors
fields.bodyText: The NHS has been accused of racial discrimination in pay after evidence showed that white senior doctors earned almost £5,000 more than colleagues from minority ethnic backgrounds. The British Medical Association (BMA) and British Association of Physicians of Indian Origin (Bapio) said the findings were part of a wider culture of discrimination against black and minority ethnic doctors, which includes job interviews, promotion, disciplinary processes, harassment and bullying. The gap in the pay received by white and BME consultants – senior hospital doctors – emerged in research published by the British Medical Journal. Prof John Appleby, the director of research and chief economist at the Nuffield Trust thinktank, said in the study: “The mean basic pay for white consultants is 4.9% higher than for BME consultants. “This is equivalent to additional basic pay in December 2017 of £387 – or, scaled up, around £4,644 a year – for white consultants.” In addition, Appleby said: “A more detailed breakdown shows that median basic pay for white consultants is higher than for all other ethnic groups, varying from around 3.5% higher than black/black British consultants to over 6% higher than mixed or dual heritage consultants.” The gap may be partly due to white consultants generally being older, and thus better paid on the basis of their experience, than BME counterparts, Appleby said. But the differentials are so wide that they “warrant further investigation and explanation”, he added. The BMA, which represents most of Britain's 250,000 doctors, voiced anger at the gap. “This BMJ study confirms that BME doctors continue to face unacceptable barriers, penalties and discrimination in the NHS. It cannot be right that in 21st-century Britain there are such wide gaps in pay between white and BME doctors in senior posts when, irrespective of their background, they hold positions to deliver the same care to patients,” said Dr Chaand Nagpaul, the BMA chair. “It unfortunately comes at a time when BME doctors are continuing to suffer from other forms of discrimination, with only 7% of senior managers in the NHS coming from BME backgrounds and staff surveys showing that BME doctors feel they are at greater risk of harassment and bullying.” He urged the government and NHS leaders to tackle all forms of discrimination within the health service. The Bapio went further in its criticism. “This BME pay gap further reinforces our view that there is widespread racial discrimination at all levels in the NHS,” said Dr JS Bamrah, the association’s chairman. He suggested some of the gap may be due to the fact that many BME consultants “historically work in unpopular specialities such as psychiatry, geriatrics, rehab medicine and so on, and mostly in rural district general hospitals where white consultants are reluctant to work”. However, he added, BME consultants also feel they are discriminated against in awards of extra pay and clinical excellence awards, disciplinary matters, in job interviews and also in getting senior management jobs in the NHS. “This is yet more evidence of racial discrimination in the NHS,” he said. Appleby found that for almost all other types of doctors apart from consultants, the pay gap between those of white and BME origin was small. Danny Mortimer, the chief executive of NHS Employers, which represents NHS bodies in pay negotiations, said the salary gap figures were “very concerning”. “It is clear that the NHS and the medical profession must address the factors that lie behind this unwarranted and unfair divergence,” he said. An ongoing government-commissioned inquiry into a major gap between male and female doctors in the NHS, which is due to report next year, should identify solutions to that problem that can also be used to close the ethnic pay gap, Mortimer added. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: “The NHS is celebrated in British society as a beacon of equality and fairness, and we are determined to see hard-working staff from all backgrounds rewarded equally and fairly – regardless of ethnicity. “The prime minister launched the race disparity audit last October for this very reason – to examine how people of different backgrounds are treated across all areas of life, and to tackle the injustices that hold people back. “We have commissioned our own data on ethnicity pay, to identify where the biggest gaps lie in the workforce, and will shortly announce robust plans to tackle these challenges head on, and as part of our long-term plan for the NHS support the workforce to progress their careers.” • This article was amended on 6 September 2018 because an earlier version referred Dr JS Bamrah as the president of the British Association of Physicians of Indian Origin. Bamrah is the chair of that organisation.
